body:
Thanks for the investigation. Makes sense to me. Can you please add a brief comment in the code? Something like:

"`cleaner` can be null if the mapped region has size 0"

I will then merge it.
Let me know if you need anything else @tcrayford.
Added a comment. Thanks!
LGTM

@hachikuji I updated the warning message based on the earlier discussion. Please let me know if you see any issues, and also your take on @ijuma's [comment](https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1499#discussion_r66838550) on the previous commit.
Thanks @hachikuji , LGTM overall. Maybe another pair of eyes from @ewencp so we can `+2` on this big patch.
FYI: A few of the connect system tests are failing. I'm investigating.
@granthenke : Ok, we can leave the code as it is for now. Could you rebase?
@hachikuji @Ishiihara @shikhar @ijuma @gwenshap

Hi @ewencp. Thanks for the review.

Agreed. I overlooked this and assumed the listings to contain the complete content.

Sorry for the noise!

@jeyhunkarimov first, sorry this has been outstanding for some time. Would you mind rebasing and then ping me so I can take another look?
One general comment - i'd like to see some tests. Thanks

Thanks for the PR. Can we please also add a test in either `AuthorizerIntegrationTest` or `EndToEndAuthorizerTest`? That way we ensure the right behaviour from an authorization perspective even if the implementation details of consumer coordinator look-up change.
@junrao Rebased on trunk.

Nearly clean system test run here: http://testing.confluent.io/confluent-kafka-branch-builder-system-test-results/?prefix=2016-08-12--001.1471006495--hachikuji--KAFKA-3888--3554fb8/. Just one failure which looks like a bug in the test case, but I'll investigate.
LGTM
There's a checkstyle failure in the Jenkins run, can you please fix?
Done
@omkreddy is this backward compatible. What happens to the clients that are on older versions are they going to get any auth exceptions
@ijuma Thanks for the review. I've added the integration test and attempted to clean up the coordinator lookup future logic.

@becketqin : Are you still working on this? There are other KIPs such as KIP-58 that will be depending on this patch. So, we probably don't want this patch to sit for too long. We are pretty close to committing this patch.

@harshach AFAIK There are no compatibility issues. Current AclCommand does't support to add Describe operation on Group Resource. This is a valid combination and we are already handling this combination.
https://github.com/omkreddy/kafka/blob/trunk/core/src/main/scala/kafka/server/KafkaApis.scala#L854
And now with passing system tests: https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder-2/79
@hachikuji @Ishiihara @shikhar @ijuma @gwenshap

@hachikuji @ewencp I'd appreciate your initial feedback on this PR. The approach I took in handling topic subscriptions is simply mimicking how regex subscriptions are handled. Of course, this breaks a number of existing unit tests, but I'd like to have some feedback early on before diving into fixing those unit tests. Thanks a lot.

Thanks for the new patch. Jenkins result shows the following failure, which seems to be related to this patch. Also left a couple of more minor comments.

kafka.api.AuthorizerIntegrationTest > testDeleteWithWildCardAuth FAILED
    java.lang.AssertionError: expected:<NONE> but was:<INVALID_TOPIC_EXCEPTION>
        at org.junit.Assert.fail(Assert.java:88)
        at org.junit.Assert.failNotEquals(Assert.java:834)
        at org.junit.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:118)
        at org.junit.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:144)
        at kafka.api.AuthorizerIntegrationTest.testDeleteWithWildCardAuth(AuthorizerIntegrationTest.scala:556)
Fixed the broken test and the minor reviews. Thanks @junrao
LGTM. Wow, that was even less work than I was expecting.
LGTM other than minor comments
LGTM. +1 for the decision not to add config from the timeout.
Thanks for the patch. LGTM

@granthenke : Missed one more comment after merging.  In AclCommandTest, could you add the delete operation to the following for ResourceToOperations so that we can test deleting a topic from cli?

```
TopicResources -> (Set(Read, Write, Describe), Array("--operation", "Read" , "--operation", "Write", "--operation", "Describe")),
```
@omkreddy : Thanks for the patch. LGTM. Could you rebase?
LGTM.
LGTM
Thanks for the PR, LGTM. Merged to trunk.
Seems to be the same as https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1723, the test needs to be updated as per that PR I think.
sorry, just ran in to this, i'll close
Tests passed locally, merged to trunk.
@junrao Absolutely. See #1730 for that follow up.
@ewencp for review. Just a minor thing that stuck out to me when going through config code
Heh I should have tried at least one of the config tests, lots failing around default configuration. Not quite sure what the nuance here is!
This is a follow-up after https://github.com/apache/kafka/commit/2e3722a234df5c0cd2e91c258cc0e4d825ee0626.
LGTM provided that the release tarball doesn't have duplicated slf4j-log4j12 and log4j jars
LGTM
It's intentional. `new String("")` is a sentinel and reference equality needs to be used for it to work as intended.
Tests passed locally. Merging to trunk and 0.10.0 branches.
Isn't this configuration deprecated?
Thanks Jun, Ismael, and Guozhang for your comments! I am on vacation right now. I will integrate your feedback when I get back in 2 weeks.
@dpkp Yes, it is deprecated but until removed I assume it will be in the documentation.
Can it be removed instead?
Thanks for the patch. LGTM too.
@junrao rebased the PR.

@junrao Sorry, I just saw your ping... Yes, I am still working on this but was distracted by something else before. I will work on this this weekend and get it done. 

I tried with 50K segments, and it took about 11 seconds to load all the segments without time index, and about 30 seconds with the time index.

I ran a bunch of tests on different machines. It seems that the machine I originally ran the tests on has some disk issue. A stably reproduceable result was that loading the segments took 3-4x longer with the time index. And what interesting is that for some of the logs with small number of log segments (e,g 100) I saw the loading time is significantly longer than other logs with much more segments (e.g. 3000). This happened both w/ and w/o time index. I am trying to see what caused this. 

I'll update the findings this weekend.
@dpkp I'm not sure in what version the support will be dropped, but I suspect it would be the next major release.
Thanks for the explanation @ijuma
@ijuma why not use `new Object()` for this? I think that's clearer about the intention.

BTW `new String("")` is really the same thing as `""` it seems,

```
scala> "" == new String("")
res0: Boolean = true
```

@shikhar `new Object()` could be used and is perhaps clearer. The code you pasted is for Scala where `==` is the same as `equals` in Java. In Scala, `eq` is the equivalent of `==` in Java:

``` scala
scala> "" eq new String("")
<console>:12: warning: comparing a fresh object using 'eq' will always yield false
       "" eq new String("")
          ^
res0: Boolean = false
```
@junrao  @nehanarkhede   Can you review the fix for this bug?  I think this bug is a serious issue, it will cause the controller not working. Thanks~
@Ishiihara @hachikuji @ijuma @gwenshap

@dguy @mjsax @ijuma This issue will cause any KStream in 0.10.0 branch with `KTable aggregation operators` to fail. The main fix is in `copartitionGroups()`, with some refactoring as well.

Also augment the unit test of `TopologyBuilderTest` to cover this bug, which unfortunately was not discovered before.

@dguy @mjsax @ijuma While working on https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1735 I think the main issue for missing this bug fix to be back ported is that the applicationID prefix logic is quite scattered in the class and with duplicate code. This PR against trunk is for cleaning up some of that logic and adding the unit test as well for `copartitionGroups`.
The build failure doesn't seem to have anything to do with the code change here. I think this is ready for review.
Thanks @omkreddy  merged into trunk

@junrao I have been running tests this afternoon. 
Actually the previous results I got have included the changes you mentioned above. In addition, in the sanity check one difference for time index is that we also check that the last indexed timestamp is greater than the first indexed timestamp. The requires reading both the first and last entry. I also commented out that check.

The broker that used to have > 40000 segments has only 12000 segments now due to the retention. So I was not able to run the tests on the 40000 partitions. I started to populate data to the cluster again. Hopefully I will have >40000 segments by tomorrow. 

One promising experiment I did this afternoon was changing the number of log recovery threads. This seems reduce the mmap time effectively. But since I do not have a 40000-segments broker this afternoon, it is hard to say if that is going to help in a large broker. I'll try this out tomorrow.

Back to the tests I ran earlier on a 40000 segments broker and this afternoon, the profiling I did was the following:
1. the time used to load each partition 
2. the time used for mmap function specifically to see if there is long mmap (>100 ms)
3. the time used in sanity check.

The profiling shows time spent on (1) is not completely related to the # of segments in the partition. For example, a partition with 1 segment may takes 35 ms to load while another partition with 12 segments only takes 4 ms to load. Even for the two partitions of the same topic that have the exact same number of segments, the time can differ by 10x from 5 ms to 50 ms. **This happens both with and without time index.**

When I look at the partitions that takes longer to load (e.g. 2 seconds w/o time index and 6 seconds w/ time index), those segments tend to be loaded later in the segment loading process.

As for time spent on (2), I did not see any long mmap when the number of segments is less than 12000, whether with or without time index. But after the # of segments is greater than 20000, some long mmap() are witnessed. Again, those long mmap call only occur on the log segments that are loaded later in the segment loading process. The loading time was pretty linear when number of segments is 12000. It took about 2 seconds to load the segments without time index, and took about 4 seconds with time index.

Regarding the time spent on (3), when we have to read both the first timestamp and last timestamp in the time index, the sanity check time significantly grew, but still short compared with the time spent on loading the files.

Based on the test I have run, it seems clear that
1. The biggest part of segment loading time is mmap(), no matter w/ or w/o time index.
2. It does not seem that loading time index is more expensive than loading offset index.

Originally the test set a timeout of 1ms to exercise the purgatory code path. It turns out the delete can actually succeed in that amount of time (see Jira) therefore setting to 0 to ensure a timeout.

cc @ijuma 

I wanted to fix this deadlock by avoiding the need to hold the lock when invoking `DelayedOperation.tryComplete()`, but it's tough to make the iteration safe without depending on a copy of the operations list somewhere. In the end, I pushed the copy to `purgeCompletedOperations()`. It seems reasonable because I think we would tend to see a number of operations for the same key complete at the same time, but I'm not entirely sure.
LGTM

Do you know if the build failure is related? Looks like it could be, but i'm unsure:

``````
Exception in thread "StreamThread-69" org.apache.kafka.streams.errors.TopologyBuilderException: Invalid topology building: Topic foo already matched check for overlapping regex patterns
    at org.apache.kafka.streams.processor.TopologyBuilder$SourceNodeFactory.getTopics(TopologyBuilder.java:173)
    at org.apache.kafka.streams.processor.TopologyBuilder.topicGroups(TopologyBuilder.java:833)
    at org.apache.kafka.streams.processor.internals.StreamPartitionAssignor.assign(StreamPartitionAssignor.java:292)
    at org.apache.kafka.clients.consumer.internals.ConsumerCoordinator.performAssignment(ConsumerCoordinator.java:259)
    at org.apache.kafka.clients.consumer.internals.AbstractCoordinator.onJoinLeader(AbstractCoordinator.java:427)
    at org.apache.kafka.clients.consumer.internals.AbstractCoordinator.access$1000(AbstractCoordinator.java:81)```
``````
Deprecated - see KAFKA-2063 instead.
This PR is WIP. It doesn't yet updated to latest revision of KIP-74

@ijuma @enothereska 

Could you please review when you have a moment?
ping @junrao for review

@junrao The file system type is xfs. Currently I have ~19000 segments on the broker. Using 10 log recovery threads, it takes about 3 seconds to load without time index and about 10 seconds with time index. If I reduce the log recovery threads number to 5, the loading time becomes 6 seconds with time index.

So it looks that the number of log recovery threads was causing the slow log segments loading. I will test this on a 25K segments cluster with time index as well after the broker reaches there.
LGTM.
Comments addressed.
@dguy did you see it from Jenkins?
LGTM
@guozhangwang yes it was in the jenkins build

@becketqin : Thanks for the info. So using more log recovery threads slows down the loading with time index?

Also, about mmap() becoming more expensive with more log segments. @enothereska mentioned to me that metadata lookups in file systems get more expensive with more open file handles since the lookups are based on an implementation of red-black tree. That's mostly CPU overhead. In your tests, do you notice any I/O activity when mmap() becomes more expensive?
@dguy I re-ran the tests locally and it works fine, also I did not see the quoted failure in latest Jenkins. So I think it may be resolved in the recent commits.
Jenkins failures are transient and irrelevant.

@guozhangwang @ewencp Rebased this against trunk. While rebasing, I noticed a problem in the heartbeat thread where we would fail to get timely notification of network events (such as heartbeat failures or coordinator disconnects) because the heartbeat was sleeping until the next needed heartbeat. I fixed this with a hard-coded maximum poll interval. Let me know if that makes sense.

This code only changes system tests, so pretty safe to say the Jenkins error is unrelated. I was also able to reproduce the error easily just by running 5-15 times. With the updates it ran > 100 times without reproducing the error.
LGTM

@tcrayford : Thanks for the patch. Looks good to me overall. Just a few minor comments. 

One thing I was thinking is on loading the partial segment into the map. I was originally thinking that if we can load at least one full segment into the map, we will still move the dirty offset at the segment boundary to avoid having to scan the partial segment more than once.  On second thought, your approach in the patch potentially requires fewer rounds of cleaning. So overall, it seems to be a more efficient approach.
Addressed @ijuma 's comments.
@hachikuji I looked through the code but get lost trying to find the hard-coded interval. Could you point it to me?
@guozhangwang It's in HeartbeatThread inside AbstractCoordinator.
@guozhangwang See notes about inconsistency with trunk. If you're ok with this, I'll defer to you as you all are managing any backports...
One very minor comment, but LGTM
Ok, given we're trying to keep things closer in sync w/ trunk, LGTM
The same unit test failed again, I will investigate it a bit further.
Addressed @ewencp 's comments.
Addressed @ewencp 's comments.
LGTM
